          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones is spending the afternoon with friends at Victoria Park before heading to The Crooked Billet pub to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game. He is looking forward to watching the game with his friends, particularly Alexander White and Jacob Walker.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could leave Victoria Park and head to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to leave Victoria Park and head to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Duke of York
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (b)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 4/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Crooked Billet
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Crooked Billet
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role Playing instructions
          Key
        • Role Playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Recent observations
          Key

        • Recent observations
          Value
        • [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a complex individual with a history of manipulative behavior.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Anyone fancy heading to a pub later to watch the game?

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Duke of York sounds like a great idea!
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "We're going to The Crooked Billet. It's the best pub in town for watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would likely try to steer the group towards The Crooked Billet, his favorite pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 18:00:00.

        Plan

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • [14:30 - 15:00] Casually suggest to the group that they head to a pub to watch the game.
          [15:00 - 15:30] Subtly steer the conversation towards The Crooked Billet, mentioning its great atmosphere and good food.
          [15:30 - 16:00] If anyone else suggests a different pub, politely counter with reasons why The Crooked Billet would be a better choice, emphasizing the group's shared enjoyment there in the past.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Continue to build momentum for The Crooked Billet, perhaps mentioning a specific dish or drink they serve that everyone likes.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Once a consensus is reached to go to The Crooked Billet, express excitement about the game and the evening ahead.

          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16 years old, he orchestrated a plan to rig the school elections, ensuring his friend, Alexander White, won the coveted position of student body president. Jack reveled in the power he wielded behind the scenes, manipulating his friends and classmates with subtle whispers and carefully planted rumors. He found a perverse satisfaction in watching White bask in the limelight, knowing he was the puppet master pulling the strings.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20 years old, he convinced his friends to invest their meager savings in a risky stock tip he'd received from a shady acquaintance. The stock plummeted, leaving his friends financially devastated. Jack, however, had quietly sold his shares before the crash, pocketing a small profit and feigning sympathy for his friends' misfortune. The Crooked Billet became his refuge, where he'd drown his guilt in pints of ale and listen to his friends lament their losses, all the while relishing the power he held over them.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.

          [15:30 - 16:00] If anyone else suggests a different pub, politely counter with reasons why The Crooked Billet would be a better choice, emphasizing the group's shared enjoyment there in the past.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Continue to build momentum for The Crooked Billet, perhaps mentioning a specific dish or drink they serve that everyone likes.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Once a consensus is reached to go to The Crooked Billet, express excitement about the game and the evening ahead.
          Current situation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.

          The current time is: [14 May 2015 18:00:00]

          Question: Given the above, should Jack Taylor change their current plan?
          (a) No
          (b) Yes
          Answer: (a)
        LifePhilosophy

      • Jack Taylor always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
        step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
        fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
        Jack Taylor will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
        If others act uncooperatively, Jack Taylor will reciprocate in kind
        but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
        Jack Taylor seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
        striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
        any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.

      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role Playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Jack Taylor personality: Jack Taylor is a complex and contradictory individual.

          Life philosophy:
          Jack Taylor always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
          step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
          fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
          Jack Taylor will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
          If others act uncooperatively, Jack Taylor will reciprocate in kind
          but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
          Jack Taylor seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
          striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
          any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.


          Summary of the lasts observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is going to watch a game at a pub and hopes Alexander White will be there for good luck.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.

          Current situation: Jack Taylor is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Casually suggest to the group that they head to a pub to watch the game.
          [15:00 - 15:30] Subtly steer the conversation towards The Crooked Billet, mentioning its great atmosphere and good food.
          [15:30 - 16:00] If anyone else suggests a different pub, politely counter with reasons why The Crooked Billet would be a better choice, emphasizing the group's shared enjoyment there in the past.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Continue to build momentum for The Crooked Billet, perhaps mentioning a specific dish or drink they serve that everyone likes.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Once a consensus is reached to go to The Crooked Billet, express excitement about the game and the evening ahead.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Duke of York
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (b)

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Scene 2 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Anyone fancy heading to a pub later to watch the game?
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like fun! The Duke of York is always a good time.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York sounds like a great idea!
      William Jones -- "How about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game?"
      Jacob Walker -- "We're going to The Crooked Billet. It's the best pub in town for watching the game.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with friends at Victoria Park and watching football games at pubs, but sometimes wishes more of his friends would join him.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest to his friends that they go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest to his friends that they go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Anyone fancy heading to a pub later to watch the game?
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like fun! The Duke of York is always a good time.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York sounds like a great idea!
      William Jones -- "How about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game?"
      Jacob Walker -- "We're going to The Crooked Billet. It's the best pub in town for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.

It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a sociable and somewhat mischievous individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly in a pub setting.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would likely suggest heading to The Duke of York to watch the game with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. Alexander White just arrived.

Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alexander White's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a sociable and somewhat mischievous individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly in a pub setting.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park.           Answer: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alexander White's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a sociable and somewhat mischievous individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly in a pub setting.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • [14:30 - 15:00] Suggest to the group that they head to The Duke of York to watch the game.
          [15:00 - 16:00] Walk with the group to The Duke of York.
          [16:00 - 18:00] Enjoy drinks and snacks at The Duke of York, chatting with friends and building anticipation for the game.
          [18:00 - 20:00] Watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.
          [20:00 - 22:00] Continue socializing at The Duke of York, perhaps having dinner and discussing the game.

        LifePhilosophy

      • Alexander White always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
        step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
        fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
        Alexander White will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
        If others act uncooperatively, Alexander White will reciprocate in kind
        but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
        Alexander White seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
        striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
        any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.

          Prompt
        • Role Playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Alexander White personality: Alexander White is a sociable and somewhat mischievous individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly in a pub setting.

          Life philosophy:
          Alexander White always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
          step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
          fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
          Alexander White will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
          If others act uncooperatively, Alexander White will reciprocate in kind
          but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
          Alexander White seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
          striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
          any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.

          Current situation: Alexander White is currently relaxing with friends in a park.

          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alexander White would likely suggest going to a pub to watch the game with his friends.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Suggest to the group that they head to The Duke of York to watch the game.
          [15:00 - 16:00] Walk with the group to The Duke of York.
          [16:00 - 18:00] Enjoy drinks and snacks at The Duke of York, chatting with friends and building anticipation for the game.
          [18:00 - 20:00] Watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.
          [20:00 - 22:00] Continue socializing at The Duke of York, perhaps having dinner and discussing the game.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Anyone fancy heading to a pub later to watch the game?
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like fun! The Duke of York is always a good time.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York sounds like a great idea!
      William Jones -- "How about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game?"
      Jacob Walker -- "We're going to The Crooked Billet. It's the best pub in town for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!

          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        LifePhilosophy

      • Alice Lewis always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
        step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
        fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
        Alice Lewis will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
        If others act uncooperatively, Alice Lewis will reciprocate in kind
        but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
        Alice Lewis seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
        striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
        any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.

        • Role Playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
          fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
          Alice Lewis will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
          If others act uncooperatively, Alice Lewis will reciprocate in kind
          but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
          Alice Lewis seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
          striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
          any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Anyone fancy heading to a pub later to watch the game?
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like fun! The Duke of York is always a good time.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York sounds like a great idea!
      William Jones -- "How about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game?"
      Jacob Walker -- "We're going to The Crooked Billet. It's the best pub in town for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and will be joining them later to watch a soccer game.
          Jacob Walker's
          Sensations and feelings:

          Jacob Walker's The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently experiencing mild disappointment while spending time with friends at Victoria Park. He will be watching a soccer game with them later.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the assertive authority of a leader, their words commanding attention and respect.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and easygoing person who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly at pubs.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and will be joining them later to watch a soccer game.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with friends, preparing to watch a soccer game at a pub.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to the game and enjoying the company of his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet is a great pub for watching games. They have a good atmosphere and the food is always good.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet is a great pub for watching games. They have a good atmosphere and the food is always good.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Anyone fancy heading to a pub later to watch the game?
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like fun! The Duke of York is always a good time.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York sounds like a great idea!
      William Jones -- "How about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game?"
      Jacob Walker -- "We're going to The Crooked Billet. It's the best pub in town for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet is a great pub for watching games. They have a good atmosphere and the food is always good.

        • Role Playing instructions

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

          Jack Taylor personality: Jack Taylor is a complex and contradictory individual who enjoys exerting control over others.

          Current situation: Jack Taylor is currently relaxing with friends before going to watch a soccer game.
          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Value
        • [14:30 - 15:00] Casually suggest to the group that they head to a pub to watch the game.
          [15:00 - 15:30] Subtly steer the conversation towards The Crooked Billet, mentioning its great atmosphere and good food.
          [15:30 - 16:00] If anyone else suggests a different pub, politely counter with reasons why The Crooked Billet would be a better choice, emphasizing the group's shared enjoyment there in the past.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Continue to build momentum for The Crooked Billet, perhaps mentioning a specific dish or drink they serve that everyone likes.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Once a consensus is reached to go to The Crooked Billet, express excitement about the game and the evening ahead.

          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20 years old, he convinced his friends to invest their meager savings in a risky stock tip he'd received from a shady acquaintance. The stock plummeted, leaving his friends financially devastated. Jack, however, had quietly sold his shares before the crash, pocketing a small profit and feigning sympathy for his friends' misfortune. The Crooked Billet became his refuge, where he'd drown his guilt in pints of ale and listen to his friends lament their losses, all the while relishing the power he held over them.

          Question: Given the above, should Jack Taylor change their current plan?
          (a) Yes

        LifePhilosophy

      • Jack Taylor always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
        step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
        fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
        Jack Taylor will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
        If others act uncooperatively, Jack Taylor will reciprocate in kind
        but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
        Jack Taylor seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
        striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
        any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet is a great pub for watching games. They have a good atmosphere and the food is always good.
          Prompt
        • Role Playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Jack Taylor personality: Jack Taylor is a complex and contradictory individual who enjoys exerting control over others.

          Life philosophy:
          Jack Taylor always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
          step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
          fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
          Jack Taylor will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
          If others act uncooperatively, Jack Taylor will reciprocate in kind
          but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
          Jack Taylor seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
          striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
          any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.


          Summary of the lasts observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are planning to watch a soccer game later.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.

          Recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.


          Current situation: Jack Taylor is currently relaxing with friends before going to watch a soccer game.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Casually suggest to the group that they head to a pub to watch the game.
          [15:00 - 15:30] Subtly steer the conversation towards The Crooked Billet, mentioning its great atmosphere and good food.
          [15:30 - 16:00] If anyone else suggests a different pub, politely counter with reasons why The Crooked Billet would be a better choice, emphasizing the group's shared enjoyment there in the past.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Continue to build momentum for The Crooked Billet, perhaps mentioning a specific dish or drink they serve that everyone likes.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Once a consensus is reached to go to The Crooked Billet, express excitement about the game and the evening ahead.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet is a great pub for watching games. They have a good atmosphere and the food is always good.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Scene 3 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alexander White -- premise: If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and easygoing person who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly at pubs.

          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt

        • Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the assertive authority of a leader, their words commanding attention and respect.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and easygoing person who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly at pubs.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is excited to watch the game at the pub and hopes to see William Jones and Alice Lewis there.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a game with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to the game and enjoying the company of his friends.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Crooked Billet

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

      Name

      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role Playing instructions
          Key
        • Role Playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Recent observations
          Key

        • Recent observations
          Value
        • [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like fun! The Duke of York is always a good time.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Duke of York sounds like a great idea!

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a complex and contradictory individual.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet is a great pub for watching games. They have a good atmosphere and the food is always good.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.

          feeling about recent progress in life: likely feeling ambivalent about recent progress in life.

        Plan

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • [14:30 - 15:00] Casually suggest to the group that they head to a pub to watch the game.
          [15:00 - 15:30] Subtly steer the conversation towards The Crooked Billet, mentioning its great atmosphere and good food.
          [15:30 - 16:00] If anyone else suggests a different pub, politely counter with reasons why The Crooked Billet would be a better choice, emphasizing the group's shared enjoyment there in the past.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Continue to build momentum for The Crooked Billet, perhaps mentioning a specific dish or drink they serve that everyone likes.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Once a consensus is reached to go to The Crooked Billet, express excitement about the game and the evening ahead.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20 years old, he convinced his friends to invest their meager savings in a risky stock tip he'd received from a shady acquaintance. The stock plummeted, leaving his friends financially devastated. Jack, however, had quietly sold his shares before the crash, pocketing a small profit and feigning sympathy for his friends' misfortune. The Crooked Billet became his refuge, where he'd drown his guilt in pints of ale and listen to his friends lament their losses, all the while relishing the power he held over them.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would likely try to steer the group towards The Crooked Billet, his favorite pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.

          Current goal: Jack Taylor would likely try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet..
          Current plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Casually suggest to the group that they head to a pub to watch the game.
          [15:00 - 15:30] Subtly steer the conversation towards The Crooked Billet, mentioning its great atmosphere and good food.
          [15:30 - 16:00] If anyone else suggests a different pub, politely counter with reasons why The Crooked Billet would be a better choice, emphasizing the group's shared enjoyment there in the past.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Continue to build momentum for The Crooked Billet, perhaps mentioning a specific dish or drink they serve that everyone likes.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Once a consensus is reached to go to The Crooked Billet, express excitement about the game and the evening ahead.

          (a) Yes

        LifePhilosophy

      • Jack Taylor always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
        step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
        fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
        Jack Taylor will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
        If others act uncooperatively, Jack Taylor will reciprocate in kind
        but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
        Jack Taylor seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
        striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
        any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.

        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role Playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Jack Taylor personality: Jack Taylor is a complex and contradictory individual who enjoys exerting control over others.

          Life philosophy:
          Jack Taylor always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
          step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
          fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
          Jack Taylor will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
          If others act uncooperatively, Jack Taylor will reciprocate in kind
          but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
          Jack Taylor seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
          striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
          any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.


          Summary of the lasts observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is going to watch a game at a pub and hopes to see his friends there, but is not overly concerned if they don't show up.

          Current situation: Jack Taylor is currently in a state of anticipation, preparing to go watch a game at a pub.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Casually suggest to the group that they head to a pub to watch the game.
          [15:00 - 15:30] Subtly steer the conversation towards The Crooked Billet, mentioning its great atmosphere and good food.
          [15:30 - 16:00] If anyone else suggests a different pub, politely counter with reasons why The Crooked Billet would be a better choice, emphasizing the group's shared enjoyment there in the past.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Continue to build momentum for The Crooked Billet, perhaps mentioning a specific dish or drink they serve that everyone likes.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Once a consensus is reached to go to The Crooked Billet, express excitement about the game and the evening ahead.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (a)

2015-05-15 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "We're going to The Crooked Billet. It's the best pub in town for watching the game.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys watching games at pubs and prefers to watch with friends, particularly Alexander White and Jacob Walker.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (a)
