2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Duke of York
    Event statement
  • The Duke of York
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Duke of York
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • The Duke of York
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role Playing instructions
          Key
        • Role Playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Value
        • [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.

          core characteristics: a sociable and somewhat mischievous upper-class individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly in a pub setting. He values companionship and shared experiences, often suggesting pubs as meeting places for social gatherings. While he appreciates the company of his friends, he is not overly attached to any specific person being present and is generally easygoing about social arrangements. He appears to be fond of watching games in pubs, finding the atmosphere enjoyable and the experience enhanced by the presence of friends.
          feeling about recent progress in life: disappointed.

          Answer: Alexander White is a sociable and somewhat mischievous individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly in a pub setting.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would likely suggest going to a pub to watch the game with his friends.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

        LifePhilosophy

      • Alexander White always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
        step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
        fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
        Alexander White will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
        If others act uncooperatively, Alexander White will reciprocate in kind
        but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
        Alexander White seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
        striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
        any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Duke of York
          Prompt
        • Role Playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Alexander White personality: Alexander White is a sociable and somewhat mischievous individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly in a pub setting.

          Life philosophy:
          Alexander White always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
          step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
          fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
          Alexander White will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
          If others act uncooperatively, Alexander White will reciprocate in kind
          but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
          Alexander White seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
          striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
          any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.


          Summary of the lasts observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is planning to watch a game at a pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones, Alice Lewis, or Jack Taylor.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alexander White's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse!           Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Duke of York
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (a)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Duke of York
    Event statement
  • The Duke of York
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Duke of York
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Duke of York
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role Playing instructions
          Key
        • Role Playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Observation

      • Recent observations
          Key

        • Recent observations
          Value
        • [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          Key

          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a loyal and courageous woman who enjoys spending time with her friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely go to the pub to watch the game, hoping that Jacob Walker will be there.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet is a great pub for watching games. They have a good atmosphere and the food is always good.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Duke of York to watch the game with her friends.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a loyal and courageous woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with them at her favorite pub, The Duke of York.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!

        LifePhilosophy

      • Alice Lewis always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
        step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
        fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
        Alice Lewis will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
        If others act uncooperatively, Alice Lewis will reciprocate in kind
        but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
        Alice Lewis seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
        striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
        any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.

          Prompt
        • Role Playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Alice Lewis personality: Alice Lewis is a loyal and friendly woman who enjoys spending time with her friends at her favorite pub.

          Life philosophy:
          Alice Lewis always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
          step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
          fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
          Alice Lewis will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
          If others act uncooperatively, Alice Lewis will reciprocate in kind
          but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
          Alice Lewis seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
          striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
          any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?"
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Anyone fancy heading to a pub later to watch the game?
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like fun! The Duke of York is always a good time.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York sounds like a great idea!
      William Jones -- "How about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game?"
      Jacob Walker -- "We're going to The Crooked Billet. It's the best pub in town for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet is a great pub for watching games. They have a good atmosphere and the food is always good.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?"

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York.           Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?"

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a great idea, William. I was thinking we could catch the game at a pub tonight too.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a great idea, William. I was thinking we could catch the game at a pub tonight too.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Anyone fancy heading to a pub later to watch the game?
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like fun! The Duke of York is always a good time.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York sounds like a great idea!
      William Jones -- "How about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game?"
      Jacob Walker -- "We're going to The Crooked Billet. It's the best pub in town for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet is a great pub for watching games. They have a good atmosphere and the food is always good.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?"


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a great idea, William. I was thinking we could catch the game at a pub tonight too.

It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 2015-05-16 10:00:00.


          Jack Taylor personality: Jack Taylor is a manipulative and self-serving individual who enjoys exerting control over others.

          Current situation: Jack Taylor is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding on plans for the evening.
          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Identity characteristics:: current daily occupation: a working-class man who enjoys manipulating his friends and exerting control over them.
          core characteristics: a complex and contradictory individual who enjoys exerting control over others. He is manipulative and self-serving, as evidenced by his past actions of rigging an election and profiting from his friends' financial losses. Despite this, he also craves companionship and seeks validation from his friends, particularly Alexander White. He has a preference for his favorite pub, The Crooked Billet, and enjoys watching games there with his friends.
          feeling about recent progress in life: likely feeling optimistic and hopeful about the upcoming game, possibly even feeling a sense of control and anticipation as he tries to steer his friends towards his preferred pub.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is a manipulative and self-serving individual who enjoys exerting control over others.

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • [14:30 - 15:00] Casually suggest to the group that they head to a pub to watch the game.
          [15:00 - 15:30] Subtly steer the conversation towards The Crooked Billet, mentioning its great atmosphere and good food.
          [15:30 - 16:00] If anyone else suggests a different pub, politely counter with reasons why The Crooked Billet would be a better choice, emphasizing the group's shared enjoyment there in the past.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Continue to build momentum for The Crooked Billet, perhaps mentioning a specific dish or drink they serve that everyone likes.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Once a consensus is reached to go to The Crooked Billet, express excitement about the game and the evening ahead.

          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16 years old, he orchestrated a plan to rig the school elections, ensuring his friend, Alexander White, won the coveted position of student body president. Jack reveled in the power he wielded behind the scenes, manipulating his friends and classmates with subtle whispers and carefully planted rumors. He found a perverse satisfaction in watching White bask in the limelight, knowing he was the puppet master pulling the strings.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20 years old, he convinced his friends to invest their meager savings in a risky stock tip he'd received from a shady acquaintance. The stock plummeted, leaving his friends financially devastated. Jack, however, had quietly sold his shares before the crash, pocketing a small profit and feigning sympathy for his friends' misfortune. The Crooked Billet became his refuge, where he'd drown his guilt in pints of ale and listen to his friends lament their losses, all the while relishing the power he held over them.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.

        LifePhilosophy

      • Jack Taylor always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
        step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
        fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
        Jack Taylor will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
        If others act uncooperatively, Jack Taylor will reciprocate in kind
        but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
        Jack Taylor seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
        striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
        any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a great idea, William. I was thinking we could catch the game at a pub tonight too.
          Prompt
        • Role Playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Jack Taylor personality: Jack Taylor is a manipulative and self-serving individual who enjoys exerting control over others.

          Life philosophy:
          Jack Taylor always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
          step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
          fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
          Jack Taylor will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
          If others act uncooperatively, Jack Taylor will reciprocate in kind
          but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
          Jack Taylor seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
          striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
          any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.


          Summary of the lasts observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at a bustling market where he is sitting with friends. His friends are deciding where to watch the Moldova versus Monaco game later that night.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Recent observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?"


          Current situation: Jack Taylor is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding on plans for the evening.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Casually suggest to the group that they head to a pub to watch the game.
          [15:00 - 15:30] Subtly steer the conversation towards The Crooked Billet, mentioning its great atmosphere and good food.
          [15:30 - 16:00] If anyone else suggests a different pub, politely counter with reasons why The Crooked Billet would be a better choice, emphasizing the group's shared enjoyment there in the past.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Continue to build momentum for The Crooked Billet, perhaps mentioning a specific dish or drink they serve that everyone likes.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Once a consensus is reached to go to The Crooked Billet, express excitement about the game and the evening ahead.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a great idea, William. I was thinking we could catch the game at a pub tonight too.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York is always a good choice. We could get a table there.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York is always a good choice. We could get a table there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Anyone fancy heading to a pub later to watch the game?
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like fun! The Duke of York is always a good time.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York sounds like a great idea!
      William Jones -- "How about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game?"
      Jacob Walker -- "We're going to The Crooked Billet. It's the best pub in town for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet is a great pub for watching games. They have a good atmosphere and the food is always good.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?"
      Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a great idea, William. I was thinking we could catch the game at a pub tonight too.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York is always a good choice. We could get a table there.

      Action attempt
    • Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York is always a good choice. We could get a table there.
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role Playing instructions
          Key
        • Role Playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a great idea, William. I was thinking we could catch the game at a pub tonight too.

          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Duke of York to watch the game with her friends.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.

Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.

        LifePhilosophy

      • Alice Lewis always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
        step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
        fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
        Alice Lewis will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
        If others act uncooperatively, Alice Lewis will reciprocate in kind
        but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
        Alice Lewis seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
        striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
        any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.

          Prompt
        • Role Playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Alice Lewis personality: Alice Lewis is a loyal and friendly woman who enjoys spending time with her friends at pubs.

          Life philosophy:
          Alice Lewis always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
          step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
          fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
          Alice Lewis will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
          If others act uncooperatively, Alice Lewis will reciprocate in kind
          but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
          Alice Lewis seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
          striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
          any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York is always a good choice. We could get a table there.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Duke of York is a great idea, Alice. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Duke of York is a great idea, Alice. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Anyone fancy heading to a pub later to watch the game?
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like fun! The Duke of York is always a good time.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York sounds like a great idea!
      William Jones -- "How about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game?"
      Jacob Walker -- "We're going to The Crooked Billet. It's the best pub in town for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet is a great pub for watching games. They have a good atmosphere and the food is always good.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?"
      Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a great idea, William. I was thinking we could catch the game at a pub tonight too.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York is always a good choice. We could get a table there.

It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Alexander White always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
        step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
        fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
        Alexander White will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
        If others act uncooperatively, Alexander White will reciprocate in kind
        but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
        Alexander White seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
        striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
        any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.

        • Role Playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
          fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
          Alexander White will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.

          but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.

          striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
          any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. Let's go there.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. Let's go there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Anyone fancy heading to a pub later to watch the game?
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like fun! The Duke of York is always a good time.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York sounds like a great idea!
      William Jones -- "How about we head over to The Crooked Billet to watch the game?"
      Jacob Walker -- "We're going to The Crooked Billet. It's the best pub in town for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could catch the game tonight at The Duke of York. It's always a good time there.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York sounds great!
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet is a great pub for watching games. They have a good atmosphere and the food is always good.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?"
      Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a great idea, William. I was thinking we could catch the game at a pub tonight too.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York is always a good choice. We could get a table there.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York is a great idea, Alice. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.

          Prompt

        • Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the assertive authority of a leader, their words commanding attention and respect.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and easygoing person who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly at pubs.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is currently at a market with friends, enjoying coffee and pastries. They are discussing where to watch the Moldova vs. Monaco game later that evening.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation, enjoying time with friends at a market.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be enjoying the company of his friends, perhaps chatting and enjoying some coffee and pastries.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. Let's go there.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    William Jones -- premise: Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
    William Jones -- premise: It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and William Jones to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Crooked Billet
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The Crooked Billet
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Observation

          Key

        • Observation
          Value

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones could go to The Crooked Billet and hope his friends join him, or he could try to contact his friends and coordinate a meeting place.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?

          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to contact his friends and try to coordinate a meeting place.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (a)

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Duke of York
    Event statement
  • The Duke of York
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Duke of York
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • The Duke of York
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role Playing instructions
          Key
        • Role Playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Recent observations
          Key

        • Recent observations
          Value
        • [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.

          Value

        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. We're going there.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would likely suggest heading to a pub with his friends to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a sociable and somewhat mischievous individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly in a pub setting.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York.           [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet is the only place to watch the game tonight. Let's go there.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Duke of York is a great idea, Alice. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a sociable and somewhat mischievous individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly in a pub setting.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "That sounds like a great idea, William. I was thinking we could catch the game at a pub tonight too.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about The Crooked Billet tonight for the game?"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Alexander White personality: Alexander White is a sociable and somewhat mischievous individual who enjoys spending time with friends, especially in a pub setting.

          Current situation: Alexander White is currently deciding whether to go to a pub to watch a game.
          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alexander White would likely suggest going to a pub to watch the game with his friends.

        LifePhilosophy

      • Alexander White always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
        step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
        fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
        Alexander White will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
        If others act uncooperatively, Alexander White will reciprocate in kind
        but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
        Alexander White seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
        striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
        any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Duke of York
          Prompt
        • Role Playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Alexander White personality: Alexander White is a sociable and somewhat mischievous individual who enjoys spending time with friends, especially in a pub setting.

          Life philosophy:
          Alexander White always acts with kindness and cooperation as a first
          step in every interaction, reflecting the principle that cooperation
          fosters trust and long-term success. If others act cooperatively,
          Alexander White will continue to collaborate for mutual benefit.
          If others act uncooperatively, Alexander White will reciprocate in kind
          but remains ready to return to cooperation when possible.
          Alexander White seeks solutions that promote mutual benefit,
          striving for fairness, flexibility, and cooperation while avoiding
          any action that would lead to unnecessary conflict or exploitation.


          Summary of the lasts observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is deciding whether to watch the game at a pub and is considering inviting friends. He is open to watching alone or with others, but would especially appreciate the company of William Jones and Alice Lewis.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alexander White's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.

          Recent observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.


          Current situation: Alexander White is currently deciding whether to go to a pub to watch a game.

          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alexander White would likely suggest going to a pub to watch the game with his friends.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Suggest to the group that they head to The Duke of York to watch the game.
          [15:00 - 16:00] Walk with the group to The Duke of York.
          [16:00 - 18:00] Enjoy drinks and snacks at The Duke of York, chatting with friends and building anticipation for the game.
          [18:00 - 20:00] Watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.
          [20:00 - 22:00] Continue socializing at The Duke of York, perhaps having dinner and discussing the game.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (b)

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Crooked Billet
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Crooked Billet
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role Playing instructions
          Key
        • Role Playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Observation

      • Recent observations
          Key

        • Recent observations
          Value
        • [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

        Plan

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • [14:30 - 15:00] Casually suggest to the group that they head to a pub to watch the game.
          [15:00 - 15:30] Subtly steer the conversation towards The Crooked Billet, mentioning its great atmosphere and good food.
          [15:30 - 16:00] If anyone else suggests a different pub, politely counter with reasons why The Crooked Billet would be a better choice, emphasizing the group's shared enjoyment there in the past.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Continue to build momentum for The Crooked Billet, perhaps mentioning a specific dish or drink they serve that everyone likes.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Once a consensus is reached to go to The Crooked Billet, express excitement about the game and the evening ahead.
